Posts.Content: I'm in the military health system, so it's expected that doctors come and go. I'm 15 months post RALP and on my third uro. The other two told me that I would have my PSA's every three months for two years, then at six month intervals until five years, then every year. My new uro put me on annual PSA's now. The NCCM treatment guide for low risk stated that a PSA should be done every six to 12 months for five years, then annually. Were my first two doctors erring on the side of caution? My third uro did consult the guidelines prior to deciding on the annual PSA starting now. What do you guys think about this? I will have an annual physical at the end of the year with my GP. I think I will talk with him about my concerns and ask him for a PSA. That way I will get a PSA every six months, at least for another year or two. BTW, I'm still undetectable at 15 months post RALP.

Posts.Content: I'm eight weeks post surgery, and like so many others that have stated, I can now pee like a racehorse. Some have stated that the flow of urine stops quite rapidly. I experience this rapid stoppage also. Within a second of the urine stopping, it feels like I am getting a bladder spasm or some sort of bladder discomfort. This discomfort around 5-10 seconds and then subsides. If anyone has ever experienced a bladder spasm, you feel a discomfort for a short time and then the spasm starts, which is usually painful. I am experiencing just the discomfort, not the painful spasm. Have any of you guys that have a forceful urination experienced anything like this?

Posts.Title: Bladder Spasm?

Posts.Content: I've been somewhat irregular for a couple of weeks so I started on Colace last week. I was out today for a Dermatology appointment when I got the urge. Before I knew what was happening, I had severe pain in my rectum. Felt like King Kong gave me a DRE. I had to pull over to the side of the road it hurt so bad. Luckily, I was able to get to a restroom shortly thereafter, and the situation was eliminated, so to speak. That is the first time this has happened even though I have been slightly constipated since surgery. I guess things aren't as healed up as I thought. Hopefully, time does heal.

Posts.Content: Chuck, your colonoscopy story reminds me of my first one when I turned 50. In the military, I had a sigmoidoscopy performed by a doctor and a tech, both male. After I retired from the Navy, I stayed in the military health system, so I just assumed my colonoscopy team would be male. I was surprised when I showed up and they were both female. The female tech looked more on the line of Sgt. Rock from the comic books, but the doctor was a very attractive Asian. They got me in there on the table laying on my side with my knees up towards my chest with my most attractive feature facing them. The tech explained the procedure and told me I could watch the monitor to see what they were seeing. We all talked about the procedure and some other things. I could feel the doctor messing with my rear for what seemed like five or six minutes. I was watching the monitor all this time. I couldn't figure out what I was looking at. Finally, I asked how they could determine if any polyps existed with what I was observing on the monitor. The doctor said that she hasn't been able to get the probe in yet because sphincter was tight as a drum. We all got a laugh out of that. I relaxed a little and the procedure went full speed ahead with no further problems. I guess I was a little more uptight because of the female presence and didn't realize it. Five years later for my second one, I was out like a light as soon as the sedative hit my IV. Next one later this year, can't wait.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind Just before your surgery, your anesthesiologist will come walking in with a briefcase full of papers for you to sign....Then he will will say "I'm going to give you something to help you relax" and that's the last thing you will remember until you wake up in recovery... Not necessarily true. It was exactly this way for my kidney cancer surgery and I thought it would be the same for my RALP. However, I remember being pushed through the passageways from pre-op to the the surgical unit. I remember seeing Mr. da Vinci standing by for my arrival, being asked to go from the gurney to the operating table, and talking to the two nurses whiles they strapped me in and hooked up the IV lines. Things got a bit hazy after that. I was cognizant of all those actions prior to the surgery and I remember all of it post surgery. I thought that was quite strange to have a memory of it all. I'm one of the people that can't stay conscious during a colonoscopy.

Posts.Content: El Dorado, when I first read your post, I thought that your were concerned about light pink blood in your stool. Then you made a comment about no bleeding when urinating. This makes me think you are talking about blood in your urine. Could you please clarify? Chuck is right about the hemis. Dark red is old blood and brighter red is fresh blood. I would think that after three months, your surgical areas would be healed enough that bleeding would not occur. But straining during a BM could start encourage hemi formation. These guys are right about seeing your doctor. Better safe than sorry.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon After starting antibiotic could no longer see blood but after 6 days started seeing it again. Used remaining antibiotics and went back to ER. I can't determine by your statement if you stopped the antibiotics then "used remaining antibiotics and went back to ER. Regardless, when a doctor gives you a course of antibiotics, you should take all of them, even though the symptoms have gone away and you feel back to normal. People stopping their antibiotics mid-course is a contributing factor in bacteria becoming resistant. Hope your ultrasound and cysto provide answers.

Posts.Content: Thanks, Chuck. Too bad there is not a test to prove that a G6 found through a biopsy is a true G6 without having to remove the prostate. Of course, even a G6 tumor can continue to grow or more could spread within the prostate that would require a prostatectomy to alleviate problems, i.e. urinary issues and ED. Would I be correct in stating that even though you have a cancer within the prostate, each one of those cancers (G6, G7, G8, G9, G10) is a different type of prostate cancer? Each cancer would remain the original G* and not progress to a different G*? I always thought that if left untreated a G6 would progress to a G7, then G8, and so on. Since G7 and above are known to metastasize, treatment of some sort is mandatory depending on the individual's age and other health issues. A person biopsied with a G6 falls into the gray area. You don't know if it's a true G6 without removing the prostate and getting a path report. And even if it is a true G6 and you don't have to worry about it metastasizing, further growth of the G6 tumors could cause you problems down the road that might require the removal of the prostate. I still feel that I made the correct decision for surgery. I am just lucky that I don't have any incontinence or ED issues. And I know that I am a true G6. A huge psychological relief.

Just stop about 3-4 hours before bedtime. Only consume enough right before bedtime to prevent dry mouth.

Posts.Title: Does a G6 PCa grow to G7, G8, G9 PCa

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH As I understand it, even with complete nerve sparing surgery, the patient usually will NEVER approach pre-op erection levels because of the trauma the nerves go through when prodded and maneuvered from the prostate. I guess that I am one of the lucky ones. I had both nerve bundles spared. I never had any pre op problems with erections. My first post op partial erection happened about eight days post op, still catheterized. As soon as the catheter was out, I had about 90% firmness. One month post op, I was at pre op levels, 100% firmness. When I relayed this good news to my surgeon, he made a statement about how easy it was for him to separate my nerve bundles from the other tissue. I guess the easier it was for him to accomplish that procedure, the less trauma the nerve bundles received resulting in my ability to achieve erections early in my recovery.

Posts.Title: How does % of the nerve bundle spared effect the ED outcome?

Posts.Content: My robotic surgery was done in a military hospital. They work in a two person team. My actual surgeon had less than 25 procedures under his belt. The senior doctor, who was the first USAF doctor to perform a RALP in 2009, had less than 300. Military doctors don't have the luxury to only perform one type of surgery as do some civilian doctors. My point is, obviously more experience is good, but surgical skills, dedication to their profession, and two heads, and eyes, are better than one. I couldn't ask for better results as I have had minimal leakage and the nerve-sparing procedure was flawless as I had pre-surgical firmness within a month of surgery.

Posts.Title: Are you not supposed to have sex before a post-op PSA test?

Posts.Content: I'm just a little older than your dad. My dad had lung cancer. They operated and discovered that it had metastasized to his rib cage. They did chemo and radiation, which burned him on the outside. I can only imagine what it did inside. It was a cruel death. I can only imagine what is going on in your dad's mind as he thinks about the fate of his dad and uncle. My dad's plight was in the early 1970's. There have been many advances in the all fields of oncology, both in understanding the disease processes and the treatment. I'm sure your dad recognizes that these medical advances exist. Talk with him and get him to acknowledge that all medical treatments have advanced in the last several years. Discuss that the treatment of his dad and uncle are outdated and that these recent advances are at least worth having an in depth discussion with an oncologist and that you would like to be present when that happens. After all, four ears are better than two. It can't hurt to talk and it could extend his life to see you married and hold his grandchildren in his arms.

Posts.Title: Dad diagnosed stage 4, refusing treatment

Posts.Content: I stopped doing the Mayo method of Kegels a few months ago. But in the course of the day's activities, I perform several tighten and release Kegels. These are done anytime that I take a leak and throughout the day when I feel that I will do something that will more than likely cause me to leak a little. So far I haven't noticed any increase in leakage compared to when I was religiously doing the Mayo method. If I do, I'll just start the Mayo method for a while then stop again. I feel that the tighten and release method is keeping that little sphincter muscle in shape, at least for me.

Posts.Content: Did you have robotic or open surgery? That's too bad about the abscess. Like you didn't have enough troubles. Just doesn't seem fair sometimes. I had kidney cancer last year and had urine leakage about a week after surgery. Back in the hospital to remove the urine and put in a drain. That didn't work so two weeks later, back in the hospital again to put in a uretal stent and another Foley. Had that in for another month. Finally got all of that out and within another month, I ended up in the ER with colitis. So three and a half months after surgery I felt good. Two months later I found out I had prostate cancer. Luckily I have come out of that ordeal without any problems. Just hang in there. Hopefully all should be OK soon. I don't understand why the doctor's are excited about 0.04 PSA ten weeks out from surgery. Usually the PSA is done at 12 weeks. Where are you located? How much experience does you doctor have with prostate surgeries?

Posts.Content: Sounds like you guys had quite the saga. My surgery was at BAMC (Brooke Army Medical Center) in San Antonio, TX. I only live 42 miles from it. I drove in on the AM of April 15th, had surgery, stayed the night, and was discharged about 9PM on the 16th. I drove myself home. I didn't experience any pain in the surgical areas but I did feel it in my rear. A BMW might be the ultimate driving machine, but not after prostate surgery.

Posts.Title: Post-surgical incontinence at 1 month

Posts.Content: I've been on atenolol for years, before and after surgery. I was lucky and was dry in about six weeks post-op. I know everyone's body reacts differently to medications, just saying. Look into Chuck's recommendation about doing Mayo Clinic method of Kegels. I had problems initially doing 50 or so kegels a day per my doctor. Started the Mayo method and it drastically reduced leakage almost immediately. Incontinence varies quite a bit, from person to person. Try the Mayo method for a couple of weeks and see if it helps. If not, then follow your doctors orders.

Posts.Title: Post-surgical incontinence at 1 month

Posts.Content: NW, I also had successful nerve-sparing surgery. You can see the results in my signature. My doc prescribed a penile pump, which I started using about one month post-op. I used it daily for almost a year. Started out at 10 min per day and worked up to 30 min per session. I did two or three sessions a day. I am as firm as I was prior to surgery and have even increased in size a little. Doc said blood flow is very important as others have stated. Do not give up.

Posts.Title: So, what do you think about this?

Posts.Content: The problem on the second time up is normal, at least to me it is. I felt the same way on both my kidney surgery and RALP. First walk I seemed energized. Second time, I thought I did something wrong. Remember, the body is placed in some weird positions for the RALP. Takes a while to get the kinks out. Everything should be fine. Until all is healed, there could be minor setbacks, but nothing to worry about. Eat healthy and drink a lot of liquids. Take a stool softener. Constipation can be pretty painful. I ended up having to use suppositories to get things going. I'm still taking Colace two weeks post surgery.

Posts.Title: Hubby is on the other side of surgery!

Posts.Content: In July 2013, I had a robotic partial nephrectomy of my right kidney due to renal cell carcinoma. The incision location that they used to remove the excised portion of my kidney had considerable amount of scar tissue and was dark red for months. Finally around nine months post surgery, the area was back to normal skin color and the scar tissue could not be felt anymore. In April 2014, I had my RALP and as you surgical survivors know, the incision above the naval was pretty gnarly. Since this incision was at least 50% larger than the kidney extraction point, I wondered how long before I got back to normal. I'm a little past the 15 month post surgery mark. The color of the incision is just a little darker than the surrounding area. I can still feel scar tissue below the incision, but it is almost gone. I know everyone heals differently. This is just some info for some of the newer guys in case inquiring minds wanted to know. As you can see, I have a lot of time on my hands.

Posts.Content: My surgeon prescribed a penis pump for use as soon as the catheter came out. I have been using it almost daily since I had my surgery in July of 2014. Not only did I not lose any length, my girth has increased quite a bit. He prescribed it to increase the blood flow to the penis since there was quite a bit of trauma due to the surgery. He said the side effect was that it would increase the girth. Win-win.

Posts.Title: Hyperthermia ????

Posts.Content: First of all, I am four months post-op da Vinci surgery. Things have gone quite well for me. I started doing Kegel's the way Chuck has previously described around week three post-op and at six weeks I was pad free. I have been doing these Kegels religiously every night. That is up until August 8th when I went on an 11 day, 3900 mile road trip. I stayed with my daughter some nights and in hotels other nights. Quite frankly, I was so tired at night I just forgot to do my Kegels for these 11 days. It was as if I had left this whole prostrate cancer episode at home. I have not experienced any negative feedback concerning leakage. So I have decided to do a little experiment. I am only going to do Kegels on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday nights. Chuck has stated that Mayo had told him he would have to do these everyday for the rest of his life. My doc told me to do Kegels, but never put a time line on it. Others have reported many different ways of doing their Kegels. Last night was the first night of this experiment. If anyone is interested, I will post periodic reports of how things are going.

Posts.Title: Diagnosis.....anxiety, depression......

Posts.Content: Welcome to the club. Steve. I initially started doing about 50 kegels per day. I found that when I only did seven Kegels at night, in bed, in three weeks, I went from two pads a day to none. Doing too many Kegels fatigues that little sphincter muscle and increases incontinence. Several people other than me have stated that reducing the number of kegels performed each day actually helped their incontinence. I am almost five months post surgery and I am doing my kegels only on M/W/F without any negative effect to my continence. Good luck. Look at the signatures of others on this forum and create one for yourself. It helps in discussing problems with others.

Posts.Title: Incontinence

Posts.Content: Welcome to the club. Steve. I initially started doing about 50 kegels per day. I found that when I only did seven Kegels at night, in bed, in three weeks, I went from two pads a day to none. Doing too many Kegels fatigues that little sphincter muscle and increases incontinence. Several people other than me have stated that reducing the number of kegels performed each day actually helped their incontinence. I am almost five months post surgery and I am doing my kegels only on M/W/F without any negative effect to my continence. Good luck. Look at the signatures of others on this forum and create one for yourself. It helps in discussing problems with others.

Posts.Title: Frequency and Urgency of Urination

Posts.Content: It seems that last year when I joined the Club, there were a lot of reports that people had incontinence problems for extended lengths of time. But now, it appears that a lot of people report of being dry by two or three months post surgery. Chuck, would it be possible to have a sticky where people could select a time frame in which they became "dry" and it be displayed in a form of a chart or some other easy way of displaying the selection rather than reading individual threads and trying to determine a trend. I don't know if this type of thing is allowed in the forum or whether anyone sees any value in it. There have been several threads that discuss incontinence. This would be a way to have everyone's results in one place and easy to see individual results. Maybe monthly up to six months then every three months for a two year total time period.

Posts.Title: Dad's catheter and staples removed today...

Posts.Content: Welcome RB151. It's too bad that you have become a member of our little club. There's a lot of info here and others will answer your multitude of questions. I don't know about Kegels prior to treatment, but Chuck's one set per day helped me out considerably. I did around 50 per day and my leakage seemed to get worse. Within a week or so of starting the one set per day, my leakage was minimal. That little sphincter does not like fatigue. Read Walsh's book, it explains a lot of things. If you read the threads on here, you'll find a lot of us have had surgery, mostly robotic, but radiation, mostly brachytherapy, has been mentioned a lot lately. Pros and cons for each. The main thing is that you have to make the decision of which treatment seems right to you. You know your personal circumstances better than anyone, so let your common sense and your heart be your guide, plus the search function on here or Google. Talk to a surgeon and a radiation oncologist to get the lowdown on each treatment. The general rule is radiation after surgery is OK, but surgery after radiation is pretty iffy. Your BPH should enter into your decision process. Obviously surgery will take care of that immediately. Some have said radiation will also help in this area, but I would talk to a radiation oncologist about this issue. With surgery, the risks of side effects (incontinence and ED) are immediate, but usually improve over weeks or months, sometimes lasting years and require addition interventions for help. With radiation, the side effects take place later on. Again, talk to the respective doctors about side effects and treatments of them. Could you please explain your Gleason score to me? I have seen it expressed as 3+3=6 or 3+4=7 or 4+3=7, but not 3-6 & 2 - 7. Good luck with this chapter of your life. Feel free to ask questions and get opinions from us. Most of us are not medical professionals, so we can only offer personal opinions. Also, create a signature as others have done so that your history is on every one of your posts. Again, welcome aboard. Pat

Posts.Title: Do Kegel Exercises Before Surgery?

Posts.Content: I had a RALP in April 2014. I had energy related problems that were finally resolved in late August. I started clearing some trees to build an addition onto my garage in early September. First day of work resulted in a very sore body. Rested my old body the next day. The next AM I awoke about 4AM with a pain in my right side. The pain continued on throughout the day and in the evening I started getting a fever. Got up to 101* plus so I got worried and went into the emergency room. Turned out that I had acute appendicitis and had to have an emergency appendectomy. Doctor said the appendix probably would have ruptured the next day. Bottom line is that if you have a pain in the lower right quadrant and you still have your appendix, you need to get some medical attention. It might save your life or prevent an enormous amount of medical problems. I also had robotic kidney surgery for a cancerous cyst in July 2013. Don't know if all of the rummaging around within my abdominal cavity caused the appendix problems or not.
